Legal_Issue: Reasonable apprehension of bias, recusal of Inquiry Committee
Governing_Law: Judges Act (RSC, 1985, c. J-1), Federal Courts Rules (SOR/98-106)
Evidence_Assessment: Role of committee counsel in cross-examining witnesses
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate reasonable apprehension of bias
Credibility_Factor: Conduct of Inquiry Committee and its counsel
Legal_Rule: Principles of judicial independence and procedural fairness
Procedural_Issue: Refusal of Inquiry Committee to recuse itself
Grounds_for_Claim: Bias due to committee counsel participating in cross-examination
Outcome_on_Merits: No basis found for substitution of Attorney General as respondent
Review_Standard: Objective standard for reasonable apprehension of bias
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Committee's actions did not compromise fairness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Testimony and procedures during Inquiry Committee hearings
Legal_Framework: Statutory and common law principles on judicial discipline
Applicant_Challenge: Motion to substitute respondent and challenge committee impartiality
Court_Result: Dismissed both Chapman’s and Attorney General’s motions
Legal_Rule_Source: Judges Act, Federal Courts Rules, case law on procedural fairness
Defendant_Response: Attorney General opposed substitution and supported committee process
Remedy_Requested: Recusal of Inquiry Committee, substitution of respondent
Authority: Federal Courts Rules, statutory framework for judicial conduct inquiries
Legal_Provision_Cited: Judges Act, RSC 1985, c. J-1; SOR/98-106
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Alleged bias from committee counsel’s participation

Outcome_of_Review: No error found in committee’s refusal to recuse

Governing_Rule: Principles of natural justice and institutional impartiality
